*** Validation triggers

    The following methods trigger validations, and will save the object to the database only if the object is valid:
    
    |--------------------+------------------------|
    | Save Method        | ^When fails validation |
    |--------------------+------------------------|
    | create             | ??? ^ Object ???       |
    | save               | false                  |
    | update             | ??? ^ Object ???       |
    | update_attributes  | false                  |
    | create!            | raise an exception     |
    | save!              | raise an exception     |
    | update_attributes! | raise an exception     |
    |                    |                        |

    The bang versions (e.g. save!) raise an exception if the record is invalid. 
    The non-bang versions don’t: 
    save and update_attributes return false, 
    create and update just return the objects.

*** git config alias.logf "log --follow"  # => create an alias for log s.t. It follows over renames
*** git mv originalfile.txt newsubdir/newfilename.txt
*** -=-=-=-=-=-= above requires a reorg of the following in this list
*** $ git add -u  # =>  Use 90% of the time. It will add updates to anything the system is already watching
*** $ git blame 
*** $ git branch -v
*** $ git branch -D local-topic-branch # HOW TO DELETE LOCAL BRANCH
*** $ git co -- .rvmrc  # => revert a file to ? before it has been added or commited
*** $ git co 4ab6b0657ac app/controllers/locations_controller.rb  # => replace with older version of locations_controller
*** $ git co $REVISION -- $FILENAME
*** $ git co <sha1> -- <path/fn>  # => checkout a specific version of a file
*** $ git co pr/999  # => go to pull request branch
*** $ git cherry-pick 17801088d5f039fe2b26526c65fe066f26f698a0
*** $ git clone git@git.hq.rbm.local:vmm.git newppm
*** $ git config --global alias.cdiff 'difftool -y -x "diff -c"'
*** $ git config --global alias.co checkout  # => setup a git alias
*** $ git diff $sha1..$sha1^ -- $file | patch -p1
*** $ git diff --name-only `git merge-base origin/master HEAD`
*** $ git diff --name-status HEAD~5 HEAD~6  # => which files changed by a commit

    In your case however, you don't need that. You want to create a new local branch that has the same state as the remote, so specify the remote branch when creating the local one with git checkout:
    
    git checkout -b my_new_branch remote/branch_name
    You would use git reset --hard if you already have a local branch (for example with some changes in it), discard any modifications that you made and instead take the exact version of the remote branch.
    
    To be sure that you have the latest state of the remote branch, use  before either checking out or resetting.

*** Postgresql analogue to mysql: SHOW TABLES
    postgresql: \d
    postgresql: SELECT table_name FROM information_schema.tables WHERE table_schema = 'public';
*** Postgresql analogue to mysql: SHOW DATABASES
    postgresql: \l
    postgresql: SELECT datname FROM pg_database;
    
*** Postgresql analogue to mysql: SHOW COLUMNS
    postgresql: \d table
    postgresql: SELECT column_name FROM information_schema.columns WHERE table_name ='table';
    
*** Postgresql analogue to mysql: DESCRIBE TABLE
    postgresql: \d+ table

*** PRIORITY NAMES for redmine tickest
      Our Redmine tickets can have a priority set and that is valuable input. However we often have tickets created with a surprisingly high priority.

      We have sent out guidance on this subject in the past but an update is in order given that we have 11 immediate priority tickets.

      Immediate - the site is down or unavailable to more than one user.
      Urgent - The issue is having a significant effect upon the client's business.
      High - This is affecting the client's business or a high priority for the client or our relationship with the client.
      Normal - The standard setting.
      Low - An issue which does not have to resolved by a particular time. "Nice to have".

      I am looking for your feedback on the text associated with each.

*** Three Verizon clients
    The wireless business - Verizon Wireless - which we normally abbreviate as VZW.
    
    The Verizon Wireless Indirects - their dealer network - VZWI.
    
    The Verizon Telecom business - that may share premises with VZW - VZT.
    
    We have a different instance of our application for each. Those abbreviations can be used as the subdomain name to access them.
    
    In Redmine, we have a different Category value for each: Verizon, Verizon Indirect and VZT respectively.

*** How to do sorting

    Where "context" is defined as Team, Project, or Worker

    If you sort it in the context of a Team this would the be called for 
    the same ticket but in the Project, and Worker contexts that it also exists in. 
    So, when a ticket is manually resorted in team Team would call this shared method on the Project and Worker. When resorted in Project it would call this on Team and Worker, etc.

    This should also work when it gets reassigned to someone new, and it the code for inserting it automatically in the list can be done with something very similar.

** [#A] GOAL: SMART

  From: 	Charles Magid <cmagid@rbmtechnologies.com>
	Subject: 	SMART Goals for Charles Magid version 0.0.1 - Fri Feb  8,  2013
	Date: 	February 8, 2013 8:35:34 PM EST
	To: 	Neil Cook <ncook@rbmtechnologies.com>


Determine & document which release 12 clients can have the release 12 base
merged into them.  Document workarounds for those which can’t.  We can
accomplish this if we have a prescribed way of getting the r12 fixes out to
client Branches.  Opinions differ on weather all branches can still be merged
into by base.  With timely feedback a combination of a workaround doc and
merges is doable.  Achieving goal would result in consistency of the common
changes being propagated out to all clients and a lessening of maintenance
for legacy code.  Expected completion by end of Q1.


Remove Gaspar's inadvertent merge of release 12 changes into release 14
development branch.  This can be accomplish using git, diff, patch, social
coding and brute force.  Achieving this goal will revert the regressions
introduced and will facilitate clean merges between the master and
development branches. I expect it to be hard to determine when this
process is complete.  but when it is reviewers should not be able to
detect the regressions made to the codebase.  We need to prevent
regressions making their way into client code.  I suggest that if the
task is not done within a month additional resources be brought to bear.


Information from client's info pages can be made available through a URI
call using Ryan's new API.  Some if not all of the Production and Staging
Environment information on Redmine web pages currently maintained by hand
could be automated.  Developers switching between machines continually
need to traverse multiple pages of the product to check on which git
branches are being deployed.  This is an annoyance and time loss for
every developer working on multiple systems. Numerous other useful
factoids can also be collected through an API. Ryan Toronto suggested a
relatively simple addition which can be integrated into the API he is in
the process of deploying to provide this capability.  It would be a
simple matter of setting up a local server to access the various systems
to get a collection of useful info currently being maintained by hand or
through this multi step process.  Creating a model to be added to Ryan's API
is relatively straight forward and provide a convenient resource. Effort is low.


Fix bugs in accordance to the evolving team requirements as they become
specified wrt testing, documentation and response time.  Conformance will
be observable in the number and content of comments within github's code
review mechanisms.  Team feedback will cause the evolution of the
requirements into a doable system.  Benefits include Cohesion,
consistency, ease of code understand and lessening of inter team friction.
There is no fixed completion date but general conformance should be
forthcoming immediately with progressive refinement during the course of
continuing development.


Active participation in challenge team 1 usability suggestions and
specifications and solutions development.  Usability may be too subjective
to measure but researching the field will doubtless lead to some means of
measuring usability.  Finding those metrics is in itself measurable and
useful in moving the company to increased client satisfaction.  Time
requirements are commensurate with that specified for the company
challenge.

*** [TRY] Following instructions http://blog.applegrew.com/2011/12/access-ext3ext2-file-system-on-mac-osx-lion-10-7/

		Fuse-ext2 is a EXT2 Filesystem support for FUSE.

		This software is based on both ntfs-3g, and ext2fuse packages.


		Dependencies
		------------

		Fuse-ext2 requires at least Fuse version 2.6.0

		- Linux:
			Fuse from http://fuse.sourceforge.net/

		- Mac OS:
			Mac Fuse from http://code.google.com/p/macfuse/


		Build
		-----

		- Linux:
			$ ./autogen.sh
			$ ./configure
			$ make
			$ sudo make install

			You can use checkinstall or some other equivalent tool to generate install
			package for your distribution.

		- Mac OS:
			Standart build:
			$ ./autogen.sh
			$ ./configure
			$ make
			$ sudo make install

			Universal build:
			$ ./autogen.sh
			$ CFLAGS="-arch i386 -arch ppc" ./configure --disable-dependency-tracking
			$ make
			$ sudo make install

			Tiger (Universal) build:
			$ export MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET="10.4"
			$ export OSX_SDK="/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.4u.sdk"
			$ export OSX_CFLAGS="-isysroot $OSX_SDK -arch ppc -arch i386"
			$ export OSX_LDFLAGS="-Wl,-syslibroot,$OSX_SDK -arch ppc -arch i386"
			$ ./autogen.sh
			$ CFLAGS="$OSX_CFLAGS" CXXFLAGS="$OSX_CFLAGS" LDFLAGS="$OSX_LDFLAGS" ./configure --disable-dependency-tracking
			$ make
			$ sudo make install

			Generating package:
			$ make package

		Usage
		-----

		Usage:    fuse-ext2 <device|image_file> <mount_point> [-o option[,...]]

		Options:  ro, force, allow_others
							Please see details in the manual.

		Example:  fuse-ext2 /dev/sda1 /mnt/sda1

		Bugs
		----

		there are no known bugs for read-only mode, read only mode should be ok for every one.

		altough, write support is available (and it is pretty stable) please do not mount your
		filesystems with write support unless you do not have anything to loose.

		please send output the output of below command while reporting bugs.

		$ /usr/local/bin/fuse-ext2 -v /dev/path /mnt/point -o debug

		Labels
		------

		please do not use comma ',' in partition labels.

		wrong: e2label /dev/disk0s3 "linux,ext3"

		correct: e2label /dev/disk0s3 "linux-ext3"

		Contact
		-------

		Alper Akcan <alper.akcan@gmail.com>

*** To do why is there a method no_floorplan and what does it really do

**** It is in floorplan.html.erb / it is a method on location

		 @location.no_floorplan?  # => always returns false

**** RUBY ON RAILS NOTE: there are many ways a model's method which returns false can be overriden.  Use of class loader which we deprecated or decorator pattern.

*** Using the GOF Decorator pattern to override methods on a per client basis <HERE>

**** PREVIOUSLY: Why we no longer put client specific override code in parrellel Client/app directories

		 	# => Ever new versions of Rails change they way they do class loading parellel structure breaks

		 rbm_root/app - main line branches
		 client01/app - client1 specific override branches
		 client02/app - client2 specific override branches

**** NOW: moved to using Decorator pattern.

		 Get around the class loading problems
		 Not brittle when class loader changes and we change version of ruby/rails

**** Here is an example:

		 	rbm_root/app/models/location.rb  # will be loaded because there is no fooling around with the class loader

		 	Decorate.model("Location", ActiveRecord::Base) do
			 	extend ActiveSupport::Memoizable
			 	include ActsAsDescribable


			rbm_root/decorators/att/models/location.rb # will be loaded because Decorate.model call ensures that avoids class load issue

			  class Location
				  belongs_to :a_region
					belongs_to :a_market
					belongs_to :a_submarket



**** We always want to use Decorators instead of class loading client classes

		 generalize, to take specific pathways through the code by way of the encapsulated DATA and not the client specific code.

		 But we have that ability using decorators.


**** Advantages to Decorators over old Class Loading mechanism

***** Less code to maintain

***** Easier to find code needing changes

***** Bugs fixed for one client will be available to other clients

#!/bin/bash

function output_help {
    echo "usage: git-revert-single-file <sha1> <file>"
}

sha1=$1
file=$2

if [[ $sha1 ]]; then
git diff $sha1..$sha1^ -- $file | patch -p1
else
output_help
fi

# generalize simple
simplegitdiff() { file=$2 ; git diff --follow $1..$1^ -- $file > rpatch.$1 ; }
simplepatch() { file=$2 ; patch  --ignore-whitespace -p1 $file rpatch.$1 ; }

# generalize fuzz

fuzzpatch() { file=$2 ; patch  --fuzz=6 --ignore-whitespace -p1 $file rpatch.$1 ; }

*** get a db

in the terminal on

$ ct vmm-test 00

this will kick off a named screen session because some of these dumps take a long time and you don't want to risk getting disconnected
run:

pg_dump -h <production db hostname> -U app <production db name> > /nfs/db_dumps/<client_name>/prod/MMDDYY_000000.sql
(obviously replacing the <foo> variables and MMDDYY should be the current date)
it will ask you for a password. Paste in the one you got from the .pgpass file on production
it will then sit there for a very long time. This means its working. When you get a shell prompt again it has completed
congratulations you've just dumped a copy of the production db and set up a copy that people can load into slots with the cap pg_load command

# Purpose: make diffing easier to visualize

#!/bin/bash
  mydiff() { base=$1 ; client=$2 ; dwdiff -A best -L -s -W " 	_}{
%'\"" -c -d ",;/:." $base $client ; }

#!/usr/bin/env ruby
  # file nmdiff.rb
  ARGV.each do|a|
    puts "mydiff ../base/#{a} #{a}"
  end

# to invoke from bash command line
  $ `nmdiff.rb app/views/feedback/search.rhtml`

# Assumptions: -
Diffs are done to a peer path where the peer is called 'base'

# TBD: -
Because of the list of special characters for the parameters to whitespace ('-W') I went through hoops to dereference.  There are better ways I just did not spend the time to figure them out (globs perhaps?)

PROBLEM STATEMENT There is a lack of leadership pertaining to the visual integrity and
usability of RBM's product(s), Causing users to become frustrated and the competition's merchandising software to
look more appealing.

SOLUTION STATEMENT Establish/hire a dedicated user experience team with the concentration of
usability, navigation and visual integrity. In addition, assure this team is a separate department and has the authority
to make the necessary decisions.

****** trez
We are still trying to figure out how to measure usability, so we can
incorporate standards in our designs,
evaluate our current product and see where to improve it.

I came across these suggested measures, which seemed very good and
worth sharing.

	•	Learnability : How easy is it for users to accomplish basic tasks
the first time they encounter the design?
	•	Efficiency : Once users have learned the design, how quickly can
they perform tasks?
	•	Memorability : When users return to the design after a period of
not using it, how easily can they reestablish proficiency?
	•	Errors : How many errors do users make, how severe are these
errors, and how easily can they recover from the errors?
	•	Satisfaction : How pleasant is it to use the design?

However, they are still difficult to establish.
If we wanted to actually make these measurements, how could we do it?
And once taken, how would we know how to make improvements,
and how long would it take to get feedback that we actually made improvements?

If we can't clarify these measures, efforts to make improvements
become a matter of taste.

Things to think about.

And one overarching theme - the best way to make real progress is to
have our employees watch real users use the product.

***** Who are we to ask
***** What is The Goal
****** trez
       We are still trying to figure out how to measure usability, so we can
       incorporate standards in our designs,
       evaluate our current product and see where to improve it.

       I came across these suggested measures, which seemed very good and
       worth sharing.

	     •	Learnability : How easy is it for users to accomplish basic tasks
       the first time they encounter the design?
	     •	Efficiency : Once users have learned the design, how quickly can
       they perform tasks?
	     •	Memorability : When users return to the design after a period of
       not using it, how easily can they reestablish proficiency?
	     •	Errors : How many errors do users make, how severe are these
       errors, and how easily can they recover from the errors?
	     •	Satisfaction : How pleasant is it to use the design?

       However, they are still difficult to establish.
       If we wanted to actually make these measurements, how could we do it?
       And once taken, how would we know how to make improvements,
       and how long would it take to get feedback that we actually made improvements?

       If we can't clarify these measures, efforts to make improvements
       become a matter of taste.

       Things to think about.

       And one overarching theme - the best way to make real progress is to
       have our employees watch real users use the product.

     4. What are some improvements we need to do make to our application to meet your future requirements?
     5. What two functions in VMM do you use most frequently?
     6. What two functions in VMM do you find most difficult?

them, rendering each post. The partial that renders the post gets a
list of replies from the database, and loops over them to render each
reply. Each post and reply requires certain external data to be loaded
from the database to properly render (user’s name, photo path, user

require 'plugman'
require 'date'

class RedminePlugin

  def initialize()
    @project_ids     = PLUGIN_CONFIG[:redmine][:project_ids]
    @redmine_domain  = PLUGIN_CONFIG[:redmine][:domain]
    @redmine_api_key = PLUGIN_CONFIG[:redmine][:api_key]
  end

  # Public: Returns an array of open ticket ids.
  #         Because the API expects strings for ids it will
  #         convert all redmine ids to strings.
  #         Guaranteed to return an array. 
  #         Array not guaranteed to have content. 
  #         Empty array incdicates there are no open tickets in the 
  #         system. 
  #         Will throw a RuntimeError if there are any communication problems
  def get_ticket_ids()
    return @last_issue_load.keys.sort{|a,b| a.to_i <=> b.to_i}.map{|k|k.to_s}
      # sorting numerically just to help facilitate debugging
      # not because it's something this API demands
  end

  # Public: returns a ticket that corresponds to the given id
  #         and this system. 
  #         The assumption is that this will only be called
  #         for tickets WN doesn't have an open ticket for.
  #         This will either be a new ticket,
  #         or an existing ticket that was closed but 
  #         WN failed to reopen when it saw the id reappear in the 
  #         list of open tickets.
  #
  #         There will be a Worker object attached to the Ticket.
  #         This will either be a worker that already exists in 
  #         the system or a new object.
  #
  #         This will NOT save the Ticket or Worker objects.
  #         WN may want to make changes the plugin doesn't support
  #         before saving.
  def get_ticket_for(ticket_id)
    load_issues() unless last_load_is_recent?
    json_issue = @last_issue_load[ticket_id.to_s]
    if json_issue.nil?
      raise "#{get_system_name()}: unable to find issue #{ticket_id}"
    end
    worker = get_worker_for(ticket_id)
    # finds or instantiates a worker
    ticket_params = {
      :system => get_system_name(),
      :uid    => ticket_id.to_s
    }
    new_ticket = Ticket.where(
     ticket_params
    ).first
    # we expect new_ticket to be nil
    # but sometimes it will be an old ticket that's 
    # just been closed and then reopened
    unless new_ticket
      new_ticket = Ticket.new(
        ticket_params
      )
    end
    new_ticket.completion_date = nil
    # in case it was an existing one that's been reopened
    new_ticket.worker = worker
    new_ticket.title = json_ticket['subject']
    # returns the ticket
    #   with attached worker

    return new_ticket
      # ready for What's Next to approve and save
  end

    # Public: returns a Worker object or nil
  #         If the ticket is not found, 
  #         or there is no-one assigned to it
  #         then nil will be returned.
  #         If a new Worker has to be instantiated
  #         it will be returned UNSAVED.
  #         May raise exceptions for failed communication
  #         or missing data.
  def get_worker_for(ticket_id)
    load_issues() unless last_load_is_recent?
    # presumes string id
    json_issue = @last_issue_load[ticket_id.to_s]
    if json_issue
      if json_issue['assigned_to'] and json_issue['assigned_to']['id']
        url = "https://#{@redmine_domain}/users/#{json_issue['assigned_to']['id']}.json?key=#{@redmine_api_key}"
        json_worker = `curl -k "#{url}" > 2>/dev/null`
        if json_worker
          # {
          #   user: {
          #     firstname:      "Bob",
          #     created_on:     "2010-04-20T15:05:39Z",
          #     last_login_on:  "2013-05-13T12:36:04Z",
          #     mail:           "bawesome@example.com",
          #     id:             3,
          #     lastname:       "Awesome"
          #   }
          # }
          worker = nil
          firstname = json_worker['user']['firstname']
          json_worker['user']['lastname']
          if json_worker['user'] and json_worker['user']['mail']
            worker = Worker.find_or_create_by_email(json_worker['user']['mail'])
          elsif json_worker['user']
            raise "#{get_system_name()}: Ticket #{ticket_id}'s assignee (#{
                firstname
              } #{
                lastname
              }) has no email."
          else
            raise "#{get_system_name()}: User info for ticket #{ticket_id} was empty"
          end
          if (worker)
            # yes, enforcing firstname lastname order.
            # You want it configurable? Send a pull request.
            worker.name = "#{firstname}#{ lastname.nil? ? '' : " #{lastname}"}"

          end
          return worker

        else
          raise "#{get_system_name()}: Unable to load user info for ticket #{ticket_id}"
        end
      end
    end
  end

  # Public: returns a string that identifies the system 
  #         that is being communicated with. As this will 
  #         be constant across all tickets from this system
  #         it will be an ALL CAPS string.
  def get_system_name()
    return 'REDMINE'
  end

  protected

  def last_load_is_recent?
    now = Time.now()
    if now.to_i - @last_issue_load_time.to_i > 300
      # if it's over 5 minutes old
      return false
    end
    return true
  end

  def load_issues()
    @last_issues_load = {}
    @last_issues_load_time = Time.now()
    @project_ids.each do |project_id|
      url = "https://#{@redmine_domain}/issues.json?limit=100&project_id=#{project_id}" \
        + "&status=open&key=#{@redmine_api_key}"
      
      offset = -100
      while true
        offset += 100
        current_url = "#{url}&offset=#{offset}"

        raw_issues = get_issues_data_for_url(current_url)
        if (raw_issues.length() > 0)
          raw_issues.each do |issue|
            @last_issue_load[issue['id'].to_s] = issue
          end
        else
          break # no mas!
        end
      end # end while
    end # end @project_ids loop
    # insert logic
  end

  # 
  def get_issues_data_for_url(current_url)
    issues = []
    raw_json = `curl -k "#{current_url}" 2>/dev/null`
    if (raw_json.length() > 0)
      data = {}
      begin
        data = JSON.parse(raw_json)
        if data['issues'] and data['issues'].length() > 0
          issues = data['issues']
        end
      rescue Exception => e
        Rails.logger.error("#{get_system_name}: problem parsing the json: #{e}")
        Rails.logger.error("#{get_system_name}: bad_json: \n#{raw_json}")
      end
    end
    return issues
  end
end

  Interesting variables are:

      `yas-snippet-dirs'

          The directory where user-created snippets are to be
          stored.  Can also be a list of directories.  In that case,
          when used for bulk (re)loading of snippets (at startup or
          via `yas-reload-all'), directories appearing earlier in
          the list shadow other dir's snippets.  Also, the first
          directory is taken as the default for storing the user's
          new snippets.

          The deprecated `yas/root-directory' aliases this variable
          for backward-compatibility.

      `yas-extra-modes'

          A local variable that you can set in a hook to override
          snippet-lookup based on major mode.  It is a symbol (or
          list of symbols) that correspond to subdirectories of
          `yas-snippet-dirs' and is used for deciding which
          snippets to consider for the active buffer.

          Deprecated `yas/mode-symbol' aliases this variable for
          backward-compatibility.

  Major commands are:

      M-x yas-expand

          Try to expand snippets before point.  In `yas-minor-mode',
          this is normally bound to TAB, but you can customize it in
          `yas-minor-mode-map'.

      M-x yas-load-directory

          Prompts you for a directory hierarchy of snippets to load.

      M-x yas-insert-snippet

          Prompts you for possible snippet expansion if that is
          possible according to buffer-local and snippet-local
          expansion conditions.  With prefix argument, ignore these
          conditions.

      M-x yas-visit-snippet-file

          Prompts you for possible snippet expansions like
          `yas-insert-snippet', but instead of expanding it, takes
          you directly to the snippet definition's file, if it
          exists.

      M-x yas-new-snippet

          Lets you create a new snippet file in the correct
          subdirectory of `yas-snippet-dirs', according to the
          active major mode.

      M-x yas-load-snippet-buffer

          When editing a snippet, this loads the snippet.  This is
          bound to "C-c C-c" while in the `snippet-mode' editing
          mode.

      M-x yas-tryout-snippet

          When editing a snippet, this opens a new empty buffer,
          sets it to the appropriate major mode and inserts the
          snippet there, so you can see what it looks like.  This is
          bound to "C-c C-t" while in `snippet-mode'.

      M-x yas-describe-tables

          Lists known snippets in a separate buffer.  User is
          prompted as to whether only the currently active tables
          are to be displayed, or all the tables for all major
          modes.

Hey, 
Find below unofficial steps I use to get freshest db dump from ATT production:
=====
1) sftp into eliot2
2) ls -la *.sql.bz2 files to see the latest dump
3) get that zip sql file
4) on your local machine unzip the file
5) cd into the location of the unzipped file
6) create a new_db
7) psql -d new_db < unzipped.sql -W 
8) wait for about 30 minutes, until u see a prompt
9) modify your database.yml as required so it refers to your new_db 

Hope that helps
-- 
- Gaspar

body: 
- |
  <p>\r
  \tThis is a Prescriptive Reset; however,&nbsp;there will be a few POP&nbsp;associated with this Reset.</p>\r
  <p style="text-align: left;">\r
  \tPlease refer to your planograms for specific placement direction.</p>\r
  <p style="text-align: left;">\r
  \t<strong><span class="caps">POP UPDATES</span></strong></p>\r
  <p style="text-align: left;">\r
  \tKey item change outs include:</p>\r
  <ul>\r
  \t<li>\r
  \t\tT-Stand Poster (vary by stores)</li>\r
  \t<li>\r
  \t\tLTE POP (new LTE locations only)</li>\r
  </ul>\r
  <p>\r
  \tThis Planogram <span class="caps">MUST</span> be followed in its entirety. Each section must be merchandised precisely as outlined in the individual Planogram sections both with <span class="caps">POP</span> and Prescriptive <span class="caps">SKU</span>.</p>\r
  <p>\r
  \t<strong><span class="caps">PRESCRIPTIVE UPDATES</span></strong></p>\r
  <p>\r
  \t<span class="caps"><strong>Smartphone Walls:</strong></span></p>\r
  <ul>\r
  \t<li>\r
  \t\t<span class="caps"><strong>Launch:</strong> Samsung Galaxy S. Android Smartphone- 4G LTE, 4.2 OS (new flavor of JB). </span>\r
  \t\t<ul>\r
  \t\t\t<li>\r
  \t\t\t\t<span class="caps">Black Mist (SKU 6060A).</span></li>\r
  \t\t\t<li>\r
  \t\t\t\t<span class="caps">White Frost (SKU 6061A).</span></li>\r
  \t\t\t<li>\r
  \t\t\t\t<span class="caps">Remove the devices from inventory for demo placements.</span></li>\r
  \t\t</ul>\r
  \t</li>\r
  \t<li>\r
  \t\t<span class="caps"><strong>Smartphone Hero Wall:</strong> Samsung GS4 in both colors (black and white) replaced Samsung GS3 Red (SKU 6013A) and Blue (SKU 69255).</span></li>\r
  </ul>\r
  <p>\r
  \t<span class="caps"><span class="caps"><span class="caps">&nbsp;</span></span></span><strong><span class="caps"><span class="caps"><span class="caps">Experience Table 1, Side 2 (Mobile Share):</span></span></span></strong></p>\r
  <ul>\r
  \t<li>\r
  \t\t<span class="caps"><span class="caps"><span class="caps">Samsung GS4- Black replaced Samsung GS3-Blue.</span></span></span></li>\r
  \t<li>\r
  \t\t<span class="caps"><span class="caps"><span class="caps">Removed AT&amp;T Mobile Hotspot Mifi Liberate (SKU 65394).</span></span></span></li>\r
  </ul>\r
  <p>\r
  \t<strong><span class="caps"><span class="caps"><span class="caps"><strong>Store Clustering- Second Cluster Launch:</strong></span></span></span></strong></p>\r
  <ul>\r
  \t<li>\r
  \t\t<span class="caps"><span class="caps"><span class="caps">The second store cluster is launching for the 4/26 reset.</span></span></span></li>\r
  \t<li>\r
  \t\t<span class="caps"><span class="caps"><span class="caps">Impacted stores will have a Critical Information message on their dashboard in iPOG outlining direction and overall impacts.</span></span></span></li>\r
  </ul>\r
  <p>\r
  \t<strong>&nbsp;*Action Required:</strong></p>\r
  <ul>\r
  \t<li>\r
  \t\tCheck your floor plan page for the orange flashing dots that call attention to Planograms that require action. Select the fixture and view the yellow highlighted items for change outs.</li>\r
  \t<li>\r
  \t\tCheck your individual Planogram pages and Critical Information for complete merchandising instructions.</li>\r
  \t<li>\r
  \t\tOnce merchandising has been completed mark the Planogram page as compliant.</li>\r
  </ul>\r
  <p>\r
  \t<strong>Reminder:</strong> Phone launch dates can and do change frequently. The phone <span class="caps">POP</span> is sent to each location in anticipation of launch. Do not put up <span class="caps">POP</span> for a phone launch that has been delayed. Keep it in a safe place and install as directed in the Planogram on day of launch.</p>\r
